text: You can compare the arena to the venerable Bojangles Arena (previously of many other names) out on Independence Boulevard, which is perfectly usable for a reasonable number of functions.  You can point to the now demolished Charlotte Coliseum, which housed the long-gone Charlotte Hornets.  The only real problem with either?  Neither was uptown, and neither had luxury boxes.  The solution?  This $400 million version, with luxury boxes, that will allegedly spur development (development that was already under way).  Was it worth it?  You make the call.You can look at the location.  Right next to several parking garages, a couple of hotels and even a light rail stop, it is well-positioned.  Yet, just as with almost any other facility, there are backups when it lets out, and the spiderweb of one-way streets uptown can make getting in and and out (if you drive) a bit of a pain.  Any better if it were elsewhere?  Not really.  That just comes with the territory: Put thousands of people into a small space, and getting them all out in a rapid fashion is going to take time.But the facility itself is a nice one.  From the brick facade greeting you as you enter to each level of seats on the inside.  While there are your expensive seats and your nosebleed seats, each of them has an excellent view of the action.  If you are fortunate enough to get into one of those luxury boxes, you will have an outstanding one.  One thing is sure - for $400 million, you do get a nice arena.  Maybe I should build one.  Can you spare any change?  Or can I at least borrow a sharpie?
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'GoodForKids': True}
categories: ['Nightlife', 'Music Venues', 'Arts & Entertainment', 'Home Services', 'Sports Clubs', 'Professional Sports Teams', 'Active Life', 'Stadiums & Arenas', 'Television Service Providers']
name: Spectrum Center

text: How is it that I manage to find my way to every home improvement store in the Charlotte metropolitan statistical area? In this case, I have no idea. I was about on the exact opposite side of town from my house, yet still I managed to wrangle my way to Lowe's.Good thing, too, as I found that they were having a sale on trees. Yes, trees. We needed a few to fill in some holes from where we had removed a few previously. Perfect. Unfortunately, they were getting rid of the trees that were out of season - or close to it - and had grown too big, which meant that they also didn't fit very well, but that's okay. It all worked out.Until they started flopping over as they grew, which means - another trip to the home improvement store.The thing I like best about Lowe's (over the large and brightly-colored competitor) is that they make it super-easy to return stuff by being able to look up purchases made on a credit card. Now I'm not saying I return anything, but if you should want to, and if you happen to have misplaced your receipt because you don't keep track of it like a good consumer, they can look up the card and you're on your way. What's that? They still can't find it? Often a merchandise credit will still be headed your way. Awesomeness.Now if I can just get them to keep taking all my money.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Lowe's Home Improvement Warehouse Stores

text: Very friendly staff, helpful with nursery planning and selection of plants - and they do have a huge amount to choose from, which makes you think that they might be visiting if the (seemingly large) selection at your local big box is no longer doing it for you. To go along with that can seem like some large prices, but the hands-on service at Pikes will perhaps make up some of the difference.They also offer some classes to help with selecting a particular plant, but it seems that some are, like those DIY classes at the big box, mostly just to get you in the door (naturally - this is to be expected). The big difference is that they serve goodies and have giveaways, which is a nice touch. Definitely worth stopping in, if nothing else, as the customer service is certainly good, even if you just want to browse around a bit.

name: Pike Nurseries

text: To go along with all those nicely-painted walls that we now had, we needed new flooring.  A ton of new flooring.  Specifically, we had decided to install new laminate - which we didn't actually get here at Carefree Carpets, but that they would install for us - new carpet and new vinyl.  Plus new carpet for the room over the garage.All in all, it was a bunch of new flooring.We actually worked with David first to see if we could come up with something for the laminate (or some other option), and we looked at a ton of different options.  Unfortunately none of them really worked for us.  The problem is that we had several colors of wood - white, oak and a couple different cherry-like colors.  That means we needed something that had a variety of colors in them.  Not circus colors, mind you, but perhaps a variation in color, rather than a single color like an oak.Generally this meant a real wood, but that would have been too thick.  So we decided to keep looking.  We ended up also looking at Lumber Liquidators and a few other flooring places, but settled on a variety from Ollie's - not one of the closeouts, but one they keep in stock - and had Carefree Carpets install it for us.  In fact, they had to install some of it twice, because one of the other contractors dropped a tool on it and scratched it up pretty badly.  Both times they did a fine job.They even installed transitions - the piece that matches up different styles of flooring - and quarter rounds (shoe moulding) that was stained to match the laminate flooring that we had picked out.  Is it perfect?  Probably not.  But it looks awfully sweet.  Even the cable guy was in the other day and mentioned that it looks nice.  The cable guy?  Seriously?  Family, friends, sure.  But the cable guy?The carpet was a bit easier, but it was complicated by wrapping things around stairs, which can be a bit of a pain.  Still, it turned out great.  Perhaps the biggest surprise was the sheet vinyl in the laundry room, which looks like tile, and turned out better than we could have imagined.Once we were done, the old bathrooms (two ceramic tile and one vinyl) looked so bad we had to use some of our old ceramic tile and get those updated.  We had Carefree Carpets do this too.  Turned out great.Now why are they called "Carefree Carpets" when they also install laminate, tile and vinyl?  I have no idea.  But it works, so I won't complain.
name: Carefree Carpets & Floors

text: Window shopping is not one of my favorite things. Back in the day, you could actually window shop for things, but this is only in certain places in certain cities - and then perhaps only at certain times of year when the displays were changed out for something interesting. If you are actually shopping for windows, it is much, much worse.Champion is one of those names that you likely see about everywhere if you are in the market for windows. They send out flyers to everyone on your street. They advertise in the paper. They put "coupons" in the remodeling flyers. They have a booth at the remodeling shows. So we had them out. And their windows are not cheap, by any means. The one saving grace is that they do offer a lifetime warranty - on both parts and labor - and they have at least been around long enough that they will likely be there when you go to ask for service under said warranty.What I would suggest is not buying their windows at full price. Multiple times a year (maybe constantly) they run sales. Within those sales periods, they run other sales that are even better, such as "buy X, get Y free". Wait for those. Then be prepared to walk away, much as if you are car shopping. If you happen to be a previous customer, you can likely use this to your advantage and get the same pricing on a new batch of windows (hopefully your prior pricing was worth getting again).The windows themselves? Totally functional. They look nice and we can see through them. I don't know that we could ask for much more in a window.
name: Champion Windows and Home Exteriors of Charlotte

text: After our experience with the folks at Hearth and Patio (Monroe Road), we went looking for another option for our fireplace doors.  The only other option we really had was the Firehouse.  We did entertain the notion of going to the other Hearth and Patio near Northlake, which is why we took the trek all the way up into this part of town, but we stopped here first.To start with, the store is a lot bigger.  By that, I mean it's huge.  However, the fireplace doors are a much smaller part of the store.  They have a small little kiosk to see the selection and get an idea of what they look like.  From that, you have to decide what you want and make selections and whatnot.  So as far as that goes, it's not quite as good as Hearth and Patio.However, the staff is so much better than Hearth and Patio, it's not even close - they are helpful, and give you advice, and help you figure out what you really want, rather than just trying to sell you something.  Big thumbs up there.Plus, when you're done - or while you're thinking - you can wander around and look at all the cool stuff for the patio, for when it warms up.  Lots of other ways to spend your money.

text: The advantage to a chain - any chain, not just a Lowe's - is that you get what you get when you go in. And there is little to no difference here. I like Lowe's better than Home Depot these days because their service is better, they really strive to help you out. It used to be that Home Depot would be friendlier when you went in. Now neither really does so - but at least if you ask for help at Lowe's, they will help you.At this location, it's a new store, and they are generally well-stocked on about everything you could need (and then some) around the house. text: It turns out that our old bank (well, credit union) was closing its Charlotte locations, and while we do a lot of transactions online, and they aren't going out of business entirely, it's just really useful to have a local branch.  Or a few dozen.We ultimately decided to give into the monster and settled on Bank of America.  I mean if we're going to have a local presence, might as well have the biggest, right?I was in this area, so stopped in, which was good, because their other branches are usually slammed.  This one typically isn't.  I don't know why.  Maybe it's all the dancing statues of liberty from the tax place across the street.Setting up the business account wasn't hard.  Neither were the personal accounts, really.  The hardest part was navigating the endless suggestive sell process - do you want a debit card with that?  How about an extra account for your dog?  Finally managed to get it all done though.Then the real difficulty began: Transferring money.  It's been decades since I used a bank (vs. a credit union), so I don't know if the problem is one of being at a bank or at Bank of America specifically, but they want to hold everything.  Not reliably, however.The first person said that under a particular amount would go through.  So I get a cashiers check for that amount.  It's held until the next day.  I can deal with that.  Then I get another.  That one is held for three days.  Huh.  After that goes through, I get another.  That one is held for a week.  So I set up an online transfer.  This only allows a tiny amount to be transferred directly from the other account directly into the Bank of America account.  What a pain.Yes, I could get one whopping check for the entire amount - but what I want to know is why a cashiers check from another financial institution (again: not a personal check) is held at all, much less for varying amounts of time.  Because I need to pay bills, I can't transfer the entire amount at once, and I'd like to get as much as possible moved, while retaining access to my money.  But they don't like to allow that (this doesn't appear to be the fault of this location in particular).Finally, it seems that they didn't order the debit cards for the accounts like they said they would.  Had that done at another branch, who also let us know that we could get our pictures on them.  Didn't even know it was an option from this branch (this is the fault of this location).  Nice.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
categories: ['Mortgage Brokers', 'Home Services', 'Banks & Credit Unions', 'Real Estate', 'Financial Services']
name: Bank of America

text: When we needed to replace our heat pump, I did a ton of research on companies - even had a few of them come in and give estimates on doing so.  Most of them were pretty close on price.  In the end, it came down to two things that helped make the decision on which one to go with.The first part of the decision was the company who made us feel the most comfortable.  There are plenty of people who come in and try and sell you something.  But right off, Rodney Bradham made us feel like he wanted us to understand what we were getting (not an easy task), rather than just slamming in a new system.  That was a pleasant difference from most of the others who came in.The second was how long the company had been around.  It isn't much of a surprise to find that there are a lot of companies out there who will sell you just about anything, but Bradham Brothers had been around for a long time - nearly 30 years.  That's a lot longer than many.So we went with Bradham, and have been very happy with the decision.  We have only had one time when the system has had a problem, and they responded, came out and fixed it promptly - all covered under the warranty.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
name: Bradham Brothers

text: There are a couple of ways to look at this one.First, we have the store itself.  It's big, it's (relatively) new, it's bright, the staff is helpful, you'll find perhaps an even better selection than at other Lowe's locations, and to make things even better, it's not far from Cheeseburger in Paradise, so it's good all around.Second, we have the location.  It sucks.  Sure, the parking lot is okay, which is a good thing in the Charlotte area, rapidly becoming known for some of the worst parking in the developed world.  But getting to the parking lot is one of the worst experiences ever.The Sam Furr Road exit has to be one of the worst in the Charlotte area.  If you live in the area, then perhaps you'll have a decent time getting into and out of this shopping center.  But if you have to use the freeway to get here, cross traffic, and get back out, good luck.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': 2, 'BusinessParking': {'garage': False, 'street': False, 'validated': False, 'lot': True, 'valet': False}, 'BikeParking': True, 'WheelchairAccessible': True}
name: Lowe's

text: Holy Cow - Bank of America art collection (Hearst Tower)This body of work is housed in a small gallery (to the left when you walk in) at the base of the court yard of the Hearst Tower.  Currently showing the body of work titled "Holy Cow" is comprises of great imagery from some of the worlds greatest photographers beginning from the 1800s into modern times (it still amazes me how much great art Bank of America actually owns....or I think they own).  I did a review on the Light Factory last year here as it was displaying Ansel Adams works, again another Bank of America collection, so as much as folks want to hate banks, they are doing society a great service my making this work available to the public when it could be hidden away in personal collections forever and never to be enjoyed by you and me.Holy cow has some great imagery of dogs, cats, cows, and even a few monkeys.....just great fun to look at and enjoy.  If you work in the city it is a nice little way to spend a lunch as the galler is small and the viewing won't take much time at all, though keep in mind, no food or drink in this particular location, though they do have 1 couch you can sit on to better comtemplate art as a whole.Bank of America has several small galleries in the city in addition to several other cities across the country. This is a great little gallery and tucked away from the main stream traffic...when I was there it was like my own private gallery.  A nice little bit of art you should check out.....I'm a photographer and I approved this message *wink*.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
categories: ['Real Estate', 'Home Services', 'Public Services & Government', 'Landmarks & Historical Buildings']
name: Hearst Tower

text: Winner of the smartest building award this sleek new kid on the corporate tower block is a sight to see...unfortunately they don't give tours.It is 786 feet tall, 48-floor (54 floors including mechanical floors) skyscraper in Charlotte, North Carolina. When completed in 2010, it was the largest building in Charlotte (in square footage), second tallest building in Charlotte, next to BoA building........funny, both in banking and construction, Wachovia was always second?Anyway, I digress.But perhaps most significant fact about this building is its LEED-Platinum certification, recognizing it as the most sustainable skyscraper in America.  Pretty fancy for a small southern town eh?!?!?Among the building's sustainable features:*Uses 22 percent less energy than similar buildings its size*90% of construction waste from building was recycled*Consumes 30 million fewer gallons of water compared to similar buildings*34 percent of the building's materials were produced within 500 miles of Charlotte*Lighting system is interfaced with window blinds to maximize natural lighting and limit artificial light*120 feet underground thousands of gallons of rainwater, groundwater and condensation is collected and filtered for use in the buildingThe lobby area is nice and there is a garden area on the 10th floor, but not open to the public.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
name: Duke Energy

text: Having lived here back when the hornets were in the old stadium..this place is heads and shoulders above the last place.For my next visit it was a date night to watch John Legend and Sade in concert.The concert was really good.  The Arena was also good as we had nose bleed seats, but the sound was good and getting drinks and access to bathrooms were easy.All and all, I am still in love with this venue.ANOTHER HINT:  If the event you attend isn't a block buster, the parking deck with the big circular drive down is right next door and only $6 or so buck for parking which is cheap as event parking goes.

text: So I blew the speakers in my luxury car......hey it's a convertible...I have to turn the music up REAL loud to hear it when the top is down *grin*.So I asked the dealership (see Hendrick Porsche review) who would they recommend to replace them and they trusted?  Freeman's Stereo Video was their choice.  Located just up the road from the dealship on Independence Blvd, they are  a full service car stereo business.Though the interior of the store is a bit sparse, they have a full line of just about anything little car gizmo you could want.  I only needed 4 speakers and they looked the car over and gave me an estimate and scheduled a time to bring the car by the next day.I arrived and they went right to work....got the speakers in and got me out both on time and a little under budget (under because they thought I'd need to replace a set of tweeters but testing turned out otherwise).The stereo is back to normal and road trips are fun again!

text: I've both rented and owned in this town.................and after spending a few  years in Chicago, I'm back in the Queen city at the height of the worst real estate market in US history (next to the depression of course) so renting was the only option I would consider.I wanted to walk to work (a bank...go figure) but some of the price in the middle of the city are Chicago.....and EVEN NYC prices?!?!?! WTF?So Gateway was a good compromise and Post properties were top notch in getting me set up.   They showed me a ton of units, helped me get enough storage in the building, plus additional parking for my convertible and a secure area along with a few discounts and very quick follow up on the first couple of fix it items I had when I moved in.Add in online rent payment capabilties and secure gated environment, it has been a great experience renting from these folks.  I'd highly recommend them.

text: How long have the Bobcats been playing here? Last night was my first time to the Arena and my first basketball game! A friend from out of town (a Cavaliers fan, go figure) picked up some great tickets and asked if I would be interested. Heck, yes!Mild security at the gates with a few people running wands and checking for metal. And then a ticket check inside. No big hassle, but then we were an hour early to get to the amazing buffet that came with our tickets. Really good food, but I don't know if they do that often or what.From the Founders level, our seats were excellent, just over one of the corners of the court. We could see everything from there. I think that even the "nosebleed" seats would do pretty well here too.Signage is good and there are plenty of helpers around to point you to your section and your seats. I found the restrooms to be spaced out appropriately and the one I visited was pretty clean, even during halftime.Prices. Yeah. $40 for four beers. How does that happen? And these weren't premium pours. Just draft Budweiser in a 20 ounce plastic cup. Crazy!We took the Light Rail to get here. Awesome ride getting in, the Arena is right next to the station. Getting back, I would recommend you pop over to the Epicenter for a beer and let the crowds drain a little before getting back on board.Go Cats!

text: Very few Yelp reviews of home inspectors so I went offline to a friend (I know, shock!) who had recently purchased a house and asked him who he had used. He was very happy with Jim Matson at Pillar to Post, so I contacted them. They were fine with my desired appointment time (Saturday morning, 9:00 AM).And when I turned up early at the house to meet the inspector, he was already underway. Wow!Very helpful, very knowledgable. I followed him around with my own little notepad, capturing the answers to questions I asked as he poked and prodded (literally, prodded!) the house, climbed up onto the roof and into the attic. Extremely thorough.And the report, OMG, wow. Forty pages of text and pictures detailing every room in the house and supplying detail of anything that looked like it wasn't right. A fantastic list of things to take to the seller.Jim has a good background in construction and since he's lived in Charlotte for years, he remembers what was going on when. So he could give excellent detail about the house that a less experienced inspector perhaps could not.I'm extremely pleased and he earned each one of those five stars.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True}
name: Pillar To Post Home Inspection

text: My lovely wife has become quite the tile and grout expert, having redone the shower and the floor of the master bathroom. So now she's got her eye on a backsplash in the kitchen. But despite searching online and at the big home improvement stores, we simply can't find a tile that we really like. I mean, this stuff is going to last at least 15 years so let's do it right.I suggested that we hit up a tile shop and so Yelp brought us here. A little overwhelming at first, Teresa took great care of pointing us to exactly what we needed. I swear we weren't in the shop for more than an hour before we'd landed on the tile and the grout, placed our order and paid for it.I am very impressed with Tile Collection. Amazing selection, great knowledgeable help.

text: I booked a truck online at uhaul.com and after an email, a text and a phone call reminder, I arrived on time to pick it up. The person who helped me with the forms had a badge that said manager and he made it appear that this is something he's done a truckload of times before.Easy, pleasy. From the time I walked in until the time I drove off the lot with my rental truck was maybe 15 minutes.Now, if the trucks could be better, that would be awesome but I can't ding these folks for that. Maybe cruise control? Or a CD player? Or even a ventilated seat? When you're driving 1000 miles in two days, all of these things would be helpful. But at least the truck was clean and it was as comfortable as it can be, I suppose.Yay! I'm a fan!

text: A quick pop in to the Home Depot for a can of WD-40 and some picture hanging hardware, I ended up also picking up an adjustable wrench and a small hammer. Oh, Home Depot, what do you have in the air that makes me want to buy so much of your stuff?I also took a nice wander down the air filter aisle (I need to get one of those, but I need to know the dang size first) and the storage aisle (large Rubbermaid containers!). Drooling, I managed to pay for my stuff at the self-service checkout before I ended up bankrupt.Good parking here and the store is like all HD's with wide aisles, good lighting, and helpful associates in their orange aprons who will cheerfully answer questions and they don't just point you towards what you're looking to find - they bring you to that aisle and make sure you're good. text: Duke has been my electricity provider since I moved to Charlotte in 2006 and they do a pretty good job of it. Sure, there are the occasional storms that cause me to run on battery for a little while but I live inside the city limits so it's rare that a power outage lasts very long.They're prompt with billing and they're prompt with taking payments. They seem to try hard to work with reducing energy usage by providing comparisons to neighbors but we're already quite efficient in that area.The Duke building in Uptown Charlotte is stunning. A massive tower of white stone and glass that stretches into the sky. The lights on the building are quite flexible so they can go with pink or blue or red or even a red/white/blue depending on the latest news or current event or political goings on that they want to support. FYI, it goes by the nickname "Voltron."Unfortunately, you need a sponsor to visit the building to get to the higher spots for sight seeing. Big bummer for that. Anyone work for Duke that would want to let me in? I'll buy lunch!I'm a fan.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
name: Duke Energy

text: Great work and a great price. It was a bit of a risk, because I never heard of them and there was no review, but I didn't have much choice. text: Reseller of telecom (cellular, digital phone, land line, internet), home security and automation, satellite television, utilities (electricity and gas), merchant (credit card processing) services we all use every day. I love ACN!!+++ easy signup using their internet portals. No stores to visit or lines to wait in. ++ customer service by phone, chat or even text message! Cool!++ with their phone service I have a desk phone I can take with me anywhere there's internet and I have free international calling!++ with their phone service I have a mobile phone voip app I can use anywhere without international roaming and long distance. ++ pick from any of the three major USA cellular networks and they have a "white label" (private brand called Flash Wireless) on which you can get a great plan for yourself or your family. + cellplatinum.com is their partner for unlocked phones at great prices delivered to your door and ready for activation on whichever network you chose. ++ if you're a business owner they also have a credit card (merchant services) partner called Anovia. Easy to use and reconcile. They even have a dongle for your mobile phone if you're a small business on the go. XOOM ENERGYThrough their partner you can get electricity and gas on your terms.+++ fixed and variable plans depending on your savvy and interest+++ green power option too! Choose to buy only power from renewable sources if you want!!!BUT MY FAVORITE ISVIVINT HOME SECURITY AND AUTOMATION+++++ fully integrated and internet enabled home automation and security. Imagine...+++'get up at night and the motion detector senses you and turns the lights on. And then turns them off 10 minutes later!+++ unlock your front door (and disarm your system) when your maintenance man rings your doorbell after you speak with him through your mobile app and then watch him on your internal cameras, all from your hotel in Paris!!!+++ be notified by text message when your spouse or child returns home, or when they don't!!The possibilities are endless, and ACN Vivint's technicians spend all day with you to set it up and make your automation dream come true!WHAT'S NEXT??I love to think what acn will get into next. Car insurance? Banking? Personal Investments? I won't be surprised! They're always in touch with the hottest thing and the coolest phones. GOTCHAS:## over several years, I've had a very few bad customer service experiences. Just escalate and a manager will ALWAYS make it right.  Or ask Tor ACN Rep and they can help you get it fixed. ## if you're a utility customer, be savvy and get informed! To get the best deal you should watch rates and lock in when the price is low.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}

text: We rented a room on the 25th floor this weekend and were floored by how awesome it was! My SIL lives in the building and six of us family members were coming to town to watch her run in the Charlotte Marathon. The spacious two-bedroom was decked out with amenities and was basically a really nice furnished apartment with everything we could ask for. It made family time so easy because we were all in the same space. The views were spectacular from that height and the sunsets were even better. Really, our stay couldn't have been better (okay, maybe if the marathon music didn't start rehearsals sooo early--but that's #westcoasterprobs). I'd stay there again and again!
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Catalyst

text: Talk about great customer service paired with sustainable practices. You'll get both when doing business with Clean Air Lawn Care. They are a power team of two arriving in good spirits to bring goodness to your lawn. They offer fertilizing treatment throughout the year, mowing, and clearing leaves. The equipment they use is mainly solar powered so both you and your neighbors can rest easy that your yard is getting maintained without all the loud noise like the gas-guzzling equipment makes. The owner communicates regularly on how they treat your lawn via detailed emails, which I appreciate since I know nothing about yard care. If you are looking to support a local business, support sustainable practices, and not do it yourself, call Clean Air Lawn Care.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'BusinessAcceptsBitcoin': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Clean Air Lawn Care

text: PROS: * The apartment units are beautiful, especially if you can get a loft (which is a top unit). Hardwood floors, stainless steel appliances, granite countertops...open and airy feel. We were fortunate to be one of the first tenants and got a unit facing the creek and trees in the back. It was so relaxing!*Salt-water pool*Quiet in the unit (perhaps it was because we had really awesome neighbors).*Maintenance is fast and friendly.*Valet trash. How lazy am I?*Gated parking garage*Friendly neighbors and events to build community within complexCONS:*Parking is tight. Even though there are a lot of spaces, they are tight and I've almost gotten hit from residents flying around the corners.*Projects are always left unfinished. For instance, they have been working on the irrigation system or something at the front entrance for the past 2 months (I think it's finally finished by now), the lounge has been in a DIY remodel for at least the past 3 months, and the shared community spaces are still waiting to be finished since they opened in August 2010.*The projects that they do complete, take way too long (see above con). After 10 months, they finally finished getting a security gate installed. Meanwhile, there were 3 break-ins to people's apartment units. Since then, however, no break-ins have been reported and I feel safe living here.*Some of the front office staff do not send a "warm" or "welcoming" vibe. Rather, I've felt intimidated to go in and ask for something. Some seem unhappy...*Communication between the management and tenants is lacking. See above. When I've gone into the office to ask about changes, they seem defensive. Perhaps because some residents are not happy with the anxiety experienced from the changes, like having 3 management properties and change in owners within the first 3 months of living here. *Rent has increased by $200 a month and no upgraded or finished amenities to justify the major price hike. *Staff said they don't reserve elevators for moves. First come, first served. Not convenient for tenants.We would have enjoyed living here longer just because of the pros. However, it's expensive rent and getting the increase motivated us to look at other options...for the same amount that we were paying in rent, we purchased a house and our monthly mortgage is similar. If you don't mind the expense, stay to yourselves in your great unit, you may like it here. However, if amenities and customer service are important, look elsewhere. There are many other apartments in Charlotte that have fabulous, completed amenities & units for the a similar price.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
name: Cielo Apartments

text: Cottage Chic has a fantastic location right off of East Boulevard. A vintage home has been converted into this business of boutique gift items. The employees were very friendly (they even offered my husband a free Charlotte magazine which scored extra points with us). They have been noted in the Charlotte magazine for winning the best place to find candles. I would have to agree. They have a large assortment. In addition, they offer boutique gifts from handbags (e.g., Kate Spade), baby products, jewelry, pjs and robes, to home linens and decor. The products mainly target women, but I'm sure you can make a guy happy with some soaps and candles too.If you want to buy a fun gift with a boutique feel, this is the place to look.

text: Seeing that I'm the Duchess of Home Depot, I really should get one of their orange aprons to prance around in while looking for my next home improvement supplies.I've got to say, I'm really impressed with Home Depot. Many years back I remember poor customer service from other locations and I stopped shopping with Home Depot. However, in the past year or two I gave them another try and I have been completely impressed with the turn around. I am greeted by almost every employee and most of them ask if I'm looking for something. They even escort me to whatever I need. There are two customer service situations that I love Home Depot for: 1) I compost. So I need sawdust to off-set the composting process. Home Depot employees will allow me to take their sawdust for free. 2) I needed new shelves. One of their employees, Gary, helped me figure out the best cost-effective way to complete my project. He cut the dimensions I needed perfectly and I was out the door in no time. I didn't have to do any math to get this done. *Bonus*I will be the first one to say, "I'm not handy!" But from the help I get at Home Depot, even I leave once in a while believing I can fix something. Thanks, Home Depot, keep up the great customer service!

text: Fantastic customer service.Plan to spend 2 to 3 consecutive hours here. Bring a coffee, take a break and eat at the Liberty across the way (or Tupelo on the second floor), and just have fun. Picking out house materials can seem like an overwhelming task. Granted, I'm not gifted at knowing what flooring pairs nicely with which backsplash tile. However, I know it when I see it. Sophia was very helpful in pairing different materials together and also getting the details down to the color of the grout (which I had no idea it even mattered). They have a terrific assortment of materials from the basic and traditional, to the classic and timeless, to the trendy and colorfully patterned. It's everything from flooring, backsplash, countertops, accent tiles to make your kitchen or bathroom amazing.

text: Home, sweet, home. If you want to deck out your home, make a stop here. You will be dazzled by all the pretty, shiny, chrome-y things. If I won the lottery, I would build a home from the ground up with Ferguson's help. It's not everyday that I need to buy faucets. Who knew they could be $555/each?! Wowzers. They also have tricky toilets that hang from the wall, thus reducing space for those tight bathrooms. Didn't check the price on that one, but I'm sure it's somewhere along the lines of an arm, maybe a leg. They have everything you need to make your house a cozy and ritzy home. Walking around I was mesmerized by all the various fixtures and endless home possibilities. If you are remodeling or building, then schedule a time to meet with one of their designers about a week or two before you need anything and they'll help you select items. Great design place, but like any savvy shopper, I'm going to have to decide where I want to invest and save. However, I'm sure I'll be back for a few major fixture needs...who am I kidding, 1 major fixture...until I win the Mega-Millions.

text: Disclaimer: This is a review of this particular store and the employee that helped us, not the company or services. Nice greeting as you enter. Didn't take long to get someone to help us. Austin was very patient and helpful! I took my mom there in hopes of advancing her to the 21st Century. I'm happy to say that she left with an iPad and iPhone.Spacious interior, comfy seating facing their three tv screens...zone out and kill time while you wait.If you can hold out, wait to purchase accessories somewhere else. You can find similar products, if not more of a selection, online and cheaper. Sorry, AT&T, I'm sure that you rely on customers to purchase from you...lower your prices or offer discounts. The parking lot is a bit tight and does not allow for a lot of parking spaces. There is a dentist and Panera Bread in the same location...so you may want to not go during the lunch rush.Thanks for the help and the great customer service!

text: It has been years since stepping foot in a Sherwin-Williams. I'm glad I did this time around because I got great service and very good quality paint. I took advantage of their 35% off sale the other weekend. They have a few different brands, one of them the HGTV brand. I like that they offer the zero VOC interior paint; no toxic paint fumes is better for everyone. The employee matched the color I needed perfectly! The paint went on smoothly. They have all the supplies you will ever need: brushes, pressure washer rentals, deck stains, etc. If you are planning your next home improvement project, stop by Sherwin-Williams and compare products.

text: The joy of home ownership strikes again. Tree branches. Definitely not a sexy home purchase, but necessary upkeep in Charlotte. I've used Heartwood twice in the past 4 years. As my neighbors tell me, they are the most expensive service. They are pricey, but to my neighbor's surprise, this last visit's quote was not the most expensive. I don't mind paying a fair price for quality service that gives me piece of mind. I appreciated their customer service. The arborist that came and helped me understand what is necessary and what is something to think about for the future. Not all the branches needed trimming, but the ones that did and were considered dangerous, they fit me into their schedule and within a week they were taken care of. Prompt and courteous, just what you want when you are dealing with house stuff.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'BusinessAcceptsBitcoin': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
name: Heartwood Tree Service

text: This company came highly recommended by a friend whose husband is in the AC business. I had a couple instances in the past year and they needed to take a look at my HVAC and got it back on track. They can usually schedule service fairly quickly.The other terrific service they offer is doing energy audits. Their auditor, Brandon, is friendly, polite, and punctual. The energy audit is comprehensive: they go under your crawl space, check ducts, go into the attic and take a read on the insulation, and they also check indoors for drafts. Within the week, you'll receive recommendations and quotes on what you can do to make your home more energy efficient. Some of the repairs, they can do.They do not clean air vents or ducts, so you'll need to find another provider for that service.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'BusinessAcceptsBitcoin': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
categories: ['Heating & Air Conditioning/HVAC', 'Insulation Installation', 'Local Services', 'Electronics Repair', 'Home Services', 'Plumbing']
name: Ross & Witmer

text: This company was able to deliver a good rate, 4.6% on a 20 year HARP refi, but terrible communication especially toward closing made it an overall terrible experience. It was so bad it felt as if they were trying to hide something.After turning in all the requested documentation I did not hear ANYTHING from them until one Wednesday I get a call saying my loan is ready to close, when can I do it, this Friday, this Saturday, or Monday? I told them I couldn't close on any of the days they offered nor could I do it next week as I would be out of town on work. Keep in mind, no one has called to review closing documents with me, to ask if I needed any explanation on the final costs, etc.The "closing coordinator" then informed me that my rate lock would expire next Friday and that she would have to talk to my loan officer, Bryan Partridge. That is when the high pressure, hard sales come into play. Bryan calls me and tells me that they would need to charge an 1/8 of a point if I wanted to extend the rate lock and that the rate lock had already been extended one week. WHAT?! I had never up to this point requested a rate lock extension, when did this happen?! "Oh, we [roundpoint financial] had to extend it one week because we made a mistake in the processing of your loan," Bryan tells me. If they had not required that extra week, I could have closed when I was not working, had plenty of time to review and ask questions about the closing costs and documents, but no, I need to accommodate them, no accommodation for the customer. Geez, I should have charged them an 1/8 point! I tried to explain to Bryan that I will be working next week, so I will be too busy to go over the documents, etc. He keeps on reminding me that the rate lock has already been extended a week and I have to keep on reminding him that I didn't request that extension. Bryan says he will need to discuss this and he will call me back. He calls back and says if he can get the closing documents to me for me to review by Friday would that be okay, because he "wants to work with me and accommodate [my] needs." Yeah what a crock of $h!t. Of course, he doesn't get me the documents by Friday, instead he gets them to me Monday evening. Of course the documents are as clear as mud. Different figures and sums in different formats (HUD documents vs roundpoint documents) so trying to figure things out was very difficult.I was working in AZ and I had to work past 3 pm everyday so by the time I got off work, roundpoint financial was already closed on the east coast, so no one to answer any questions. I would email my "senior" loan officer, Bryan, but if and when he responded, he would often not answer all my questions or answer them very vaguely, e.g. "we already discussed that." I did get a closing requirements letter from their closing coordinator. On that letter, it was clearly stated I had the right to rescind the loan after closing, this made me feel a little better. That didn't last long. When it came time to finally sign the documents with the notary, it was a hot, sticky mess. Supplemental documents that were initially given to me to review, were not in the actual closing documents for me to sign and vice versa. The notary wanted me to sign documents that were not initially given for me to review. I told the notary I could always rescind, but the she, the notary, has to inform me that I could not since this was an investment property. I think that is p!$$ poor when the notary, who doesn't know anything about the closing costs, has to explain the details of the loan to me. Overall, if you do choose to work with this company be very cautious and suspect of everything they do. Do not be afraid to ask questions, demand answers, scrutinize numbers, or even walk away. I would avoid Bryan Partridge. Even though he is a "senior" loan officer, I think that means he is good at high pressure sales and avoiding questions.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Roundpoint Mortgage Company

text: A friend of mine used to live at the Cotton Mills and we used to love going to hang out at his loft-style apartment.  Everything looked so modern and retro (although having modern/retro furniture helped).  One night, we rented some space on the rooftop for a party where we had a counter, etc. to put our food and drink...and cake!  It was a beautiful evening and we had a great view of the city (although I hear the new Vue building is going to ruin that view; ironic, isn't it?).  The location of the Cotton Mills is awesome, too.  Walking to everything Uptown is a definite convenience.  The downsides?  The price, of course.  You definitely have to pay a premium to live right in Uptown.  And one of my friends had their car broken into in the visitors' lot of the parking garage.  The only thing that I didn't like about the loft apartment itself was that there were no doors between the bedroom and the kitchen and living room to which it connected.  There was just an entryway.  Nice if you live alone, but...   I guess that's what you get for a loft apartment, though -- everything's wide open.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Camden Cotton Mills

text: Furniture is a little bit of mystery to me. I mean, I have some, but I'm always impressed when I see friend's homes so gorgeously decorated with plush and comfy pieces, modern touches and fantastic accessories. When I heard that High Cotton Home was opening, I was more than excited to check it out! The space (previously EQ3) hasn't changed too much inside, so it's still a nice, long store with plenty of walking room and ample space to check out the wares. The furniture is fantastic - accessible and chic. These are the types of pieces I would love to have in my home when I move/redecorate. They're comfy without being worn, modern but not uber trendy and beautifully classic. While you won't find Rooms To Go prices here, these pieces are higher quality so expect to pay a bit more. However, I also saw a smattering of market samples - with sofas in the $1200-$1600 range for really great fabrics and styles. You'll find everything from lamps to dressers to beds to chairs to coffee tables - and each piece is really special and unique. Plus, the owners are incredibly nice people and more than willing to help you find whatever you're looking for to make your house a home. I'm definitely a fan of High Cotton and I imagine many others will be too.

text: HUGE, clean, fun. Yes, indeed, those are three adjectives that accurately portray TWC Arena. I've been to TWC Arena for a few concerts and one Bobcats basketball game - and every time I leave there, I'm always saying to myself - wow, that's a really nice arena. The staff in every aspect have been great - nice ticket takers, kind will call holders, funny concession peeps and more. And, seriously, that's pretty amazing for this large of a venue. In addition, there are so many options for food & beverage. Granted, you'll pay for  - you'll pay a lot for it, but I'm pretty sure everyone knows that going in.Parking is pretty much a breeze, as there are tons of parking decks nearby that will lead you right to the arena. Plus, you can always take the light rail right into the city if you're drinking the Uptown parking haterade. Here's hoping that TWC arena will continue to bring great acts to Charlotte and always improve upon their facility!

text: I've always wondered about the large, pretty white building right off of South & East boulevards. And then  I heard about a Tidbits launch party launching at Alexander Scott...a new interiors and home furnishings biz housed in that very building! First of all, it's huge. It's a very large building. And there is so much merchandise gracing every room. It's nicely laid out, if a bit crowded, with custom furniture, ready made pieces, candles, bedding, jewelry, cards, paintings, and beautiful home goods. I even spied some vintage chandeliers and suitcases in the mix! There are two levels to explore so be ready to spend a bit of time in the store searching through all the treasures. While I really enjoyed the beautiful furniture and fabrics, there were a few extra bright spots worth mentioning: -Alexander Scott has a great selection of jewelry. Very impressive and uber affordable. This was a shocker to me. Pretty cuffs from $25-$50, necklaces from $40-$100, etc. All sorts of styles, materials and tastes. -There's a fantastic collection of handmade greeting cards (on both levels). Many of these items are crafted by local and regional artists. My favorite? A card that simple read, "You are the Milli to my Vanilli. Girl you know it's true." Hell to the yeah. -The staff were welcoming and very sweet. No uppity attitudes here. If you're shopping along East Blvd., Alexander Scott is a fantastic stop...for your home, yourself or to snag a gift!
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True}
name: Alexander Scott

text: Besides my husband and brownies, my iPhone is one of the great loves of my life. Since AT&T is currently the only carrier to host service for my precious iPhone, I stopped by my local store to order up the iPhone 4. Now, sometimes mobile carrier stores can vaguely resemble used car dealerships. No, not because they sell used stuff, but because they can just be filled with jargon, slick sales pitches and mile-long contracts. Not so much at this AT&T store. It's purty inside, filled with tons of fun, shiny phones and accessories. The store is impeccably clean and there are some sweet flatscreen TVs near the back of the store that you can oogle while you wait. It's important to note that every employee we worked with was super friendly, helpful and courteous. And dressed so nicely, natch!While the salespeople may lean hard on the iPhone, I was there to order my iPhone 4 anyway no hard pitch needed. Hubs and I worked with Tyler and Malcolm to transfer my old phone to hubs, set up family plan and order my new, shiny iPhone 4. Both of these guys were super patient and helped answer all of my (surely irksome) questions that I had. This AT&T store is sharp and inviting inside and out. Regardless of my occasionally questionable reception, I plan to stick with AT&T...especially if they keep carrying Apple products!

text: Packing up and moving your life across the country can be pretty hectic. This task lands on the bottom tiers of "things I enjoy." text: I love shoes. Sometimes I love them too much - and by that I mean I will wear the crap out of my shoes. text: I probably step foot into a bank three times per year. Seriously....I'm more of an ATM kind of girl. So, it makes me all giddy inside to report that this Bank of America is not only clean and sparkly, but it's filled with really nice tellers, efficient services and a notary. Woot.I rolled up to this BoA to grab some cash (many ATMs outside and drive through, folks) and more importantly, to acquire a certified check. These are the errands that I truly despise, because past experience has shown that certified checks can be obnoxious and take a while. Plus, I also needed a notary. Another potentially laborious process. But guess what? The very nice teller took care of my certified check in 5 minutes and directed me to their notary just a moment later. And the icing on the cake? The notary service was free. Yeah - I should have known beforehand that banks provide their customers with free notary services, but, frankly, I never really thought about it. While I'll continue to be an ATM kinda gal, it's nice to know that folks inside this bank are getting the job done.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True}
categories: ['Home Services', 'Mortgage Brokers', 'Banks & Credit Unions', 'Financial Services', 'Real Estate']
name: Bank of America

text: While I have yet to fall in love with Time Warner Cable, I absolutely feel that they deserve (and earn) another star because of my recent interactions with their Twitter handle and help group, @TWCableHelp. I wish the sales team was as awesome, efficient and helpful as they are. I was having a nagging problem with my Movies On Demand feature - it was freezing on me, then not playing, then not starting, then not buying movies at all. It was incredibly annoying that I couldn't watch my purchased movie! I used the @TWCableHelp handle and one of the support reps tweeted me back within minutes. After a few interactions, I direct messaged my account name and number to one of the support techs and they diagnosed the problem and assisted in a full restart of the system. Bam, movie back on, and I was able to play it continuously. If you have a more complicated issue that they can't handle remotely, they can schedule a tech visit with you over Twitter, too. Is this tech group going to change my entire opinion of TWC? No, but I'll tell you one thing, next time I have any sort of tech problem with my cable service, I'm going to tweet to their Twitter handle first before waiting on the phone for an obscene amount of time. Yay technology.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
categories: ['Internet Service Providers', 'Home Automation', 'Television Service Providers', 'Professional Services', 'Home Services', 'Security Systems']

text: Note that my review was removed by yelp - as this business appears under multiple sites.  This was the Ohio based branch that made my move and is the one that I am reviewing.-------This review represents the culmination of several months of wrangling with one of the worst companies I've ever had the DISpleasure of working with, and one of the most painful customer experiences that I've ever had in my life here on earth. I will break the review into a couple segments for clarity.This is a painful review to write, and I will make sure this review goes to both Angie's List and Yelp as well as Movers.com.Bullet Points:Overpromise, Underdeliver. High Pressure Sales tactics. Poor customer service and follow up. I quote: "You'll be satisfied with our service. We'll make you happy. We're very proud of our Angie's list B+ rating"The Plan:Day 1: 8-12 am arrival, half day to pack.Day 2: Transport to target cityDay 3: 8 am delivery.Actual:Day 1 arrival: 4:30 pm. Stopped work at 10:30 pmPromised to restart packing at 8:00 am and finish by 10:30 the next day.Much wrangling with the operations part of their service who had very different sets of plans for us. Changes in pricing. Insurance offered. We ultimately took it due to the large numbers of disconcerting elements to the service. Call backs were not performed - we had to call them ourselves to finish conversations with the company. The team hadn't eaten all day, and were very fatigued upon arrival, so we fed them.Day 2 arrived at 8:20, finished packing 3:00 pm, after multiple push backs.My parents, in their 70s were to wait at target site. The personnel promised to be mindful of my parents age and assured us that they would update us if there would be further delays. At least to take care of my parents.Day 3: Texted to get information from personnel, and were told they'd be 20 minutes late since they had to get breakfast (reasonable). 9:30, still no arrival. Once they arrived, it became clear that they would not be able to complete the task themselves (these were not large, muscular workers) and we hired several additional workers to help them finish the job - with the help of building management.It is impossible to overstate how much we tried to inform the company the particulars of the new site, which were not internally conveyed to their moving team.Damages to several appliances and statues noted on arrival. Claims filed a little while after to their claims department. The claims were denied, but their email was sent to the wrong address and we never received follow up until we pursued the matter ourselves. They later told us they received a bounced email, but didn't bother to check the email address they had used to send to us.At any rate, all claims were denied as they don't cover appliances or statues - which was not made clear to us at time of purchase of insurance. What's the point of insurance if it doesn't cover anything?Phone calls from management were non-existent.Summary:Horrid experience. Lowest rating possible.Highly unprofessional.Avoid if at all possible.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True}
name: Roadrunner Moving & Storage Cleveland

text: I stayed here for about 3 months a while back for business. :: Rooms ::The rooms are pretty spacious. The rooms I've stayed in had a kitchen with appliances, a sitting area with a L shaped couch that could be pulled out into a bed, and a huge Queen sized bed. The bathroom is decent sized with a shower-tub combo. The heating is a bit wonky and may or may not work as well as you'd like in the winter. The last week I was there, I was in a fireplace suite and that was pretty cool- the fireplace is gas powered. :: Noise ::The noise levels aren't too bad. Most people who stay here are on business so it is pretty quiet. If you have a room that faces the street (Prospect Ave), you may hear loud music and patrons from nearby bars- especially from the one across the street that doubled as a venue for salsa dancing.:: Food ::If you're staying for a while, they do have the complimentary grocery shopping. They'll just add the grocery bill to your room. In the mornings,  they serve breakfast buffet style on the 2nd floor. Items include coffee, tea, juice, water, cereal, toast, muffins, yogurt, fruit, hot oatmeal, eggs, bacon, sausage, and the like. In the evening, they'll serve different dishes everyday during their "social hour." They also serve alcohol including red and white wine and beer on tap (usually a domestic like Miller and a Great Lakes brew). They also have their 24hr marketplace in the lobby where you can pick up stuff.:: Laundry ::They have a laundry room on site. However, it was malfunctioning the few times I used it so I don't recommend it.:: Gym ::They do have a mini gym in the hotel. Not sure if it is still the case, but hotel guests were allowed to use the gym in the arcade/mall next door by showing their key cards. :: Parking ::This is one of the scariest lots I've ever encountered. If you're getting a rental, I highly recommend a compact/sub-compact/economy car as the spaces are REALLY TIGHT. Heck, the structural pillars make it even worse. In the beginning of my stay, it was about $8/day. Later on, the price jumped to $16/day.It may not be the glitziest hotel downtown, but it is affordable, spacious, near bars and restaurants, near the sporting/concert venues, and near the freeway on-ramps.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': True, 'RestaurantsPriceRange2': 2, 'WiFi': 'free', 'ByAppointmentOnly': True}

text: Leo's LaundromatI saw a sign a few weeks back advertising free wifi. I needed to wash my comforter and immediately thought of this place. Lou K and I both brought our dirty loads (pun intended) here on a Monday afternoon. The interior is cute with a 50's vibe, including vinyl chairs and reproduced vintage kitchen tables. You don't need quarters here, just cash which you can put in the x-changer machine (yes, x-changer machine). The attendant knows the regulars and spotted me as a newbie immediately. She called me honey a dozen or so times and reminded me of a cross between my country grandma and a former coworker named Aida from my days at Subway in Wooster, Oh. We fit my bedding into one of the giant washers. I used two separate dryers for the next part. I believe the entire process cost about $6. It took about an hour, but I used the wifi while I waited. Is it the cleanest place in the world? No, which I can't understand because you would expect plenty of access to soap and water. Also, a lot of thought was placed on creating a comfortable environment when it comes to the free wifi and cute dxc3xa9cor. So why not spiff it up with a good detail? I wouldn't give this place 4 stars except that I've never seen a "nice" laundromat; I believe all of our expectations are lower for laundromats over other types of retail businesses. Warning: It is hot in there.

text: There are not a ton of apartments to chose from that are close to B-W's campus. Berea has anti-student laws that prohibit students renting houses (although some still do it). As a result, T.I.P. is one of the more popular places for B-W students to reside. I have nothing against curries or other pungent SE Asian meals, in fact I love them, but I don't like my apartment to smell like it 100% of the time. I am not sure what they do at T.I.P., perhaps teleport the scents and aromas from simmering pots at a local Thai eatery directly into the HVAC of their building, but most of the interior smells of a spicy red curry. Also, a friend of mine is pretty sure she lived below a group of redneck, cowboy wicans. She thinks one of them vexed her while they were doing laundry together. I would only live here if I was looking for cheap student housing.
name: Tower In the Park

text: Need a fountain or a statue for your yard? Waldo's is the place to get it. Waldo's had a huge selection of large pots and planters, as well as fountains and statues. They also had a trellaced area with chains hanging down for hanging baskets. This doesn't seem like it would be off putting. But it was. Imagine a dark room with nothing but long chains haging...like 50 of them. It reminded me of something from a horror movie...like it was a serial killer's den. text: Last fall Lumber Liquidators sub-contracted N&M Floors to install sub-floor and bamboo throughout the main level of my home.  Some ups and downs with this company--to be fair, a lot of the issues my husband and I endured were caused by Lumber Liquidators' lack of transparency and poor management of their vendor--but overall satisfied with N&M.Positives first.  The 3 men who put in our floor did a great job.  Ed seemed to be the one in charge, and the guys were fast workers.  Each day they commuted from OH to my house outside of Pittsburgh, arriving a little before 8AM and wrapping up at 2-something in the afternoon.  On the 3rd and final day they finished up around noon.  I appreciated that they did a sufficient quick clean-up before leaving each day.  The guys were fun and pleasant and since I work from home asked if I was OK with their playing music and if the music was too loud.  I actually got a kick out of the music--mostly 80s rock and pop hits, and the guys had a tendency to sing along.  One negative was that we didn't have the best experiences with Tony, who did the initial consultation and was our N&M contact prior to the start of the job.  Consultation went fine, but then Tony was nearly impossible to reach.  Calls and texts went unanswered, and Tony insisted that he didn't receive our messages.  There was a period of time when we couldn't even get a definitive confirmation of the work start date.  Lumber Liquidators and the N&M secretary apologized profusely and assured us that Tony would soon respond.  It got pretty bad, but eventually Tony got back in touch with us and made a second trip to our home to inspect post-demo--we saved close to $3,000 by removing the old hardwood ourselves--and to confirm that everything was ready for the installation.Another negative, though not as frustrating as the first, involved the installation of some of the bamboo, from an aesthetic standpoint.  The vast majority of our bamboo was a darker color, but in our many boxes there were also some lighter-colored planks.  Ideally the lighter planks would have been mixed in with the darker planks in a way that I like to describe as "perfectly random," similar to how boxes of tiles are shuffled prior to installation.  That wasn't done, so the result in my living room is a very large section of all-dark bamboo and then a few oddly placed lighter planks.  When I first addressed this with the crew there was some frustration, then understanding, and then no further issues with the rest of the hardwood installation.  If you have strong feelings about your floor being "perfectly random" or another preference, then I urge you to very clearly discuss your expectations before the work starts.There was an awkward moment at the end of the job when it was time to write the check to N&M.  The paperwork I received via USPS prior to the start of the job quoted a price that included materials and labor, but the price at the end of the job was considerably more.  Whoever prepared the early paperwork had neglected to factor in labor costs.  Ed made a quick phone call, and N&M honored the lower price.  No complaints there!Good company.  This review would have been an easy 4 stars had Tony been more reliable and communicative.
attributes: {'ByAppointmentOnly': True}
name: N&M Floors

text: The Gupta Permold Corp. is the company that makes the diamondLife brand of garage organization and renovation products.I recently had my garage finished - from a raw, unfinished state, to a sharp looking, organized garage - and I utilized a number of items from the diamondLife brand to make it look great as well as be extremely functional.I ordered two 8 x 4 pieces of the Slatwall MX - in an alternating pattern of diamond plate and brushed aluminum, with black inserts for the slats, and aluminum trim end pieces; a 2 x 3 diamond plate pegboard (to hang hand tools), and a bunch of hooks and hardware to hang off both the Slatwall MX and the pegboard.All of the hardware they shipped looks sharp and the finished product looks even better in my garage. I now have my ladder, shovels, hoes, brooms, and a whole lot more neatly and smartly hanging off the walls.If you are looking to renovate and organize your garage, definitely check these guys out!You can view their line of garage gear here:http://diamondlifegear.com/

text: After some frustrating apartment hunting, I stumbled into the Walnut on Highland. Finally, something with new finishes, open layouts, high ceilings, a nice walk-able location, and still has some old-school charm and architecture.The staff is fantastic, friendly, professional and helpful. They've worked hard to ensure that I'm happy, and are quite responsive to issues. I had some noise problems with HVAC that required substantial trial and error, but they were persistent until it was resolved.The neighbors are friendly, fun, and... neighborly. Its nice that the management often has social events for the tenants so you can meet each other.Utilities are pretty inexpensive. I have a 2br, and the highest the heating/electric bill went (with Ethical Electric Green Energy) in January was 740kWh, about $100. Not bad! Water is fixed and included with rent as a fee.However, the building is not without some quirks and issues:* There aren't lights where there really ought to be - like in a dark, isolated hallway closet where you can't see your clothes.  Or above where the dining room table should go! * The floors aren't real hardwoods, they're cheap laminate. At least I don't have to worry about scratching them.* The paint on the walls somehow marks with the slightest scratch or brush up against it. Its like they put on a single coat, and the paint has carbon or something to show wherever it was touched.* The elevator has a beautiful glass wall in it, yet the windows to the exterior are covered in either bird poop or concrete droppings. Visitors are like "OOOOhhh!" followed by "Eeeeewwww". Its kind of embarrassing. * The place is locked up like Fort Knox. Its nice that it is secure, but holy cow, its super annoying if you're trying to host a party. You or somebody have to go down the elevator to let somebody in EVERY TIME. There is no way to buzz somebody up. Going from the lobby entrance to your unit requires at least 3 badge swipes. Garage to the unit requires FIVE badge swipes! (Garage entrance, garage vestibule, lobby vestibule, lobby, elevator). I curse out loud every time I have to walk in carrying something. Really, they need to make a real security desk in the lobby.* Lots of construction noises due to East Liberty Transit Center renovations. This usually starts around 7:30am every day. This isn't in the property's control, but something to consider about location. With East Liberty projects scheduled all around us, I don't expect outside noise to be getting better within the next few years.* The pet fee is insanely high. 1/2 a month rent for a cat?! I paid it, because I love my cat, but there is no way she could possibly do that much damage to an apartment for any amount of time. It isn't even refundable. Silly.Overall, I'm happy with the place and the problems above are most definitely "first world problems", but for the price premium that we pay for a luxury apartment, I expect a little more. Until The Odeon, Eastside III, and Bakery Square 2.0 projects are completed, this or a few private loft condos are basically your only option for a contemporary place in the neighborhood.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: Walnut on Highland

text: I could not recommend these movers. While the owner, JC was very friendly and helpful in setting everything up on the phone, and they were available the day I needed on fairly short notice, so many things went wrong and my move was extremely stressful. The movers arrived late. They used my tools to disassemble furniture, dumped a socket set everywhere, and didn't organize them. Packing went way over the expected time, past my management companies hours, at which point they were going to charge me extra. Movers started rushing, being careless. They left many items behind, completely didn't pack a closet. I ended up spending several hours moving stuff they missed. Movers got into a verbal altercation at the moving truck with each other. I had to walk away because I thought they may start physically fighting. They crammed stuff completely wall-to-wall in the elevator, knocked off the protective mats. At the destination, the movers tried moving the truck while the ramp was attached, and ended up hitting a neighbor's truck with the ramp. Amazingly, it didn't appear to cause damage. Again, I had to walk away because I just couldn't watch them. At the destination, the movers requested that I unload a wardrobe box so they could re-use it (seriously?) I complied, and when I came back downstairs, I noticed the strong smell of gas in the kitchen. One of the movers had bumped the knob on the range, left it pouring gas into the kitchen, and NOBODY NOTICED!? THE MOVERS NEARLY BLEW UP MY NEW HOUSE! Liquor bottles were packed upside-down, leaking everywhere. Water left in a kettle when it was packed - everything was wet. Original canvas paintings were placed in a wardrobe box, no protection from each other, and damaged due to the corners of each other. Basically all but one of my lamps were broken. Broken glasses, bowl, missing parts to my keyboard stand & coffee table, scratched my desk, damaged the apartment walls. A wall clock went completely missing. None of the boxes were labeled, so at the destination, everything ended up on the first floor except for wardrobe boxes - many of which didn't actually contain clothes. I was moving boxes up and down constantly during unpacking. On the plus side, I was reimbursed for the lost/damaged items. It took a month and a half to get the check, but I did. I've hired movers several times now, and unfortunately, this was the worst experience I've had. Sadly, I cannot recommend them.

text: I stayed at the Pennsylvanian for about a month in one of the Corporate Apartments.  This place is old.  I believe it used to be a hub for trains and buses.The outside looks nice but the hallways to the rooms look a little dingy.  There was mildew on the floors of my bathroom and bathtub.  The washer and dryer was old.  There was rust on some of the door hinges.  The dresser, fixtures, coffee table, dining table, and dining chairs looked new and modern.  The carpet for the most part was clean.  The sofa looked old and was not comfortable.  The bedsheets had yellow stains on them.  I did not use the comforter and one of the layers.  The Pennsylvanian has a maid service option with 1 week or 2 week intervals.  I am not sure if they even changed or washed my bedsheets because they all had the same yellow stains?  wtf?The views from the apartment is nice, but the windows are hard to see through since the window screens are dirty.The kitchen is ok.  The corporate apartment comes with a fullsized fridge, dishwasher, coffee maker, silverware, platewear, pots and pans.  There is also an iron and ironing board.  There is also a 22 inch? CRT-TV with about 100 cable channels.  I had a router for internet but it was taken away from me 2 weeks into my stay.  The Pennsylvanian claimed Comcast took it away without even telling me.  They did not offer me a chance to pay for it.The fitness room was nice.  There are treadmills, elliptical machines, pullup bars, and other various machines.  There are even a few sets of dumbells.  I never used the sauna, so I cannot comment on that.There is a 24 hour concierge that is always helpful and friendly.  There is also an option to sign up for a dry-cleaning service, which is outsourced to another company.  You drop your dirty clothes into a room and pick it up a few days later after it has been cleaned.  This is rather expensive as well.  Everyone who has a dry-cleaning Key has access to this room.  Thieves could come in and steal your clothes.If I had an option, I would not stay at the Pennsylvanian again.
attributes: {'BusinessAcceptsCreditCards': False, 'ByAppointmentOnly': False}
name: The Pennsylvanian Apartments

text: As much of a fan I am of Marriott properties, this one is a disappointment.  Management was great.  Breakfast was passable.  But the unforgivable discrepancy was in the bathroom.
